displayed_text: Patient: …when we make the decision, we’re going to have to weigh it on what what you’re telling us. Uh so you kind of know where I’m coming from. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: Um what is where you’re coming from at this point? What is it that you would suggest? What would - Doctor: I think there are like two broad ways to tackle this. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And at this point in time they are mutually exclusive. And in the future the two are probably going to be combined, but right now they are mutually exclusive. One is to give a radio therapy in the absence of hormone therapy. In other words try give you a non-hormonal treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Such as radiation instead of hormone therapy in order to delay you know the need for hormone therapy. And the other is to start the hormone therapy now and try to combine it with something that may make the hormone therapy work better and longer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: From what I’m hearing and reading between the lines, what I think I’m hearing is that you’d rather try at this point in time something that is a non-hormonal approach such as radiotherapy. And if that is the case, I think that we have an interesting study that I could talk to you about which is using what we call stereotactic radiotherapy. It’s also called CyberKnife because the company that makes the machine that delivers the radiation is called CyberKnife. It’s not a knife; it’s a misnomer. It’s not surgery – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But because the beam of radiation is so precise, it’s called a knife because it’s as precise as a surgeon’s knife. Um if you think that I’m misunderstanding and you really are more open to the hormone therapy option as well or instead of radiation and we also have a trial in that category which is trying to ask the question about whether all hormone therapy in conjunction with a new hormone therapy is better than just the old hormone therapy by itself, the conventional.

Patient: Okay. Is that the – Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Okay. That was a shot once a month or? Doctor: That was the pills you were taking. Patient: Oh, I did take them. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that would say if we did that just as a course of action and the likelihood it’s gonna help you is pretty low. Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the –

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that, that is also in the back of my mind. And, because, because then I feel like we might have actually harmed you by missing the opportunity to give, you know, an FDA-approved therapy. Of course, that would be through K___ because that would be standard therapy. Um, so that’s what the other part of my thinking. Patient: Okay. And, and from my perspective, I didn’t believe that this was going to be easy from the, from the beginning. I remember when I came, I came to J___ H___ for a reason. I came here for a consultation because I wasn’t comfortable, uh, with the options that I believe K___ was offering. I came initially for that reason. It’s strange that it was my dentist, so we talk about a lot. It’s strange how you get into certain things, uh, by having relationships with people who have gone through it. My dentist had, uh, numerous family members, had dealt with cancer, and he had recommended, he said, you know what, D___, this is what you need to do. You need to go to one of the teaching hospitals either here in DC you can go to J___ H___, in B___, and from my perspective, there are enough individuals that have come to J___ H___, that are close friends of mine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That said, they shared with me that, uh, if you have a choice, go to J___ H___. So when I came up, my thing was the consultation. We had the consultation. I left, and, uh, and I didn’t say anything. But there was a follow-up that was set for J___ H___. And we sat down, and we talked about this. So we have all these options here. We did the genetic testing. And I said, okay, this is an option just like anything else. If it does not work, it’s not like it’s the only option that we have. Doctor: Correct. Patient: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work. Doctor: Right. Patient: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks. Family Member: Three weeks. Patient: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized. Doctor: Um hum.

Family Member: I’m like, wow. Patient: My, gosh. We was in Langa, and then Langa- Doctor: So did, was that part of the tour to see that or that was just you could not see that in just where you were going? Patient: Everything was part of the tour. Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. It’s all included. Patient: Everything is, and then you have some passages- Doctor: I mean, like the poor areas of the country, that was part of the tour, or you just look out the window and that’s what you see? Patient: When, when we went to Langa, that was, that was different than where they was going. So we, we, they had a package to go to Langa. We went to- Doctor: What’s Langa? Patient: Langa is a little town. Family Member: It’s a little town outside of Cape Town. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So along the way there with you say ‘well gosh what else do you need to take the samples for’ when you know us we do lots of research here. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So parts of that, I think we talked about this the last time, when I take extra samples I will then do actual research stuff on that… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …which includes you know growing it outside of you, putting it in mice, working with all – all sorts of other things. For me to do that I have to have a consent form that we’re gonna go over. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um and uh this will allow me use with along with our other researchers for future use. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um so you can see it was important for me to talk to the radiologist to make sure that we can do it safely and that we can get enough samples to make it worth everybody’s while. Okay. Questions. Patient: Um n- well observations. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They – it it did say for example…

Patient: Or bend it backwards. The right side ain’t bothering me. It’s just that one that, well, the one that the screw came loose. Doctor: Okay. And, huh, any numbness or tingling? Patient: What? In my neck? Doctor: Your arms, your legs. Patient: No. And the only other thing that now and then is my shoulder blade from the day, from the first day that I was operated on. I was telling the nurse and everything while I was still in the hospital it felt like I had three shoulder blades at times. In fact, I told you that. Doctor: Is that getting worse? Or is it just present? Patient: No. It’s about the same. Doctor: Okay. How’s your heart been? Patient: All right. I woke up this morning. I’m not being smart, but (laughs) Doctor: Okay. But not- no chest pain? Patient: Oh, no, no chest pains. No. Doctor: Okay. How’s your hot flashes?

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But in combination they need to see how the drug levels behave. Patient: How many days will I have to be there? Doctor: I think there are two long days, but you’ll have the full schedule of how often you have to come in. Family Member: So this is a different clinical trial. Is it a clinical trial? Doctor: Different than the one he’s on. Yes. Family Member: Yeah so we’d be on two clinical trials? Doctor: Well this one you’ll just be in follow-up. You won’t be actively on this particular one. Family Member: So the Xtandi… Doctor: So you’ll be off active treatment from our current clinical trial because you’ve progressed technically. Patient: So I wouldn’t be part of that clinical trial? Doctor: You’d still be part of it for follow-up reasons but not actively on. So you wouldn’t get the Xtandi from this particular clinical trial Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And to be together. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So everything we’ve done so far is to try to keep the ball away from the glove. (Beeping) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The cancer sometimes will evolve a form of the glove that doesn’t need a ball. It, it still works. Patient: I see. Doctor: All the things it does downstream without the ball. We’ve been testing that as part of this trial. So I need to dig into the group that’s testing and find out are you one of those guys that was positive? Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you were positive, that would mean pretty strongly that we shouldn’t try more hormone treatments. You need to be positive for that to go on this immune trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh they’re looking for folks who might have more aggressive hormone insensitive cases. So I’m, I’m going to do that this week just to find out.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Retired: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Retired

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So, let me see if you want. Do you want to do it today? Patient: I mean Doctor: You can go over and do it. Patient: What? Doctor: To the treatment area. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You have an appointment there anyway. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay?

Family Member: Will he need to have somebody come with him? Doctor: Uh, no, but how is he going to – do you have transportation arrangements made? Family Member: He drives. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: He drives. Shit. J__ drives everywhere. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Is for the biopsy that we will need to do – Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - for the study and on the day that he’s just starting something new- Family Member: Yeah. Right. Doctor: I would- Family Member: You want somebody here. Doctor: At least tell you that you need to be available if we need to call you.

Patient: Yep. Doctor: A pro-antibiotic once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Calcium or Vitamin B once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Cranberry extract once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Vitamin B-twelve once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: four pills a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: You know. You have a drug, so it’s one pill each morning. Patient: Yep. For two weeks. Two weeks off, two weeks on.

Patient: No. Doctor: That’s good. Um. Platelets are normal. (pause) Patient: Mmmm. I didn’t see that. (pause) Doctor: Six five oh, yeah, two months ago. So, you said you did read the scans or? Patient: Well, I saw them, you know, in the lab works screen. I didn’t, I didn’t look at the —- I mean, I couldn’t see the bone scans or anything like that. They don’t post those. Now, the PSA wasn’t posted when I looked at it, uh, this morning. Doctor: Umm, (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Ummm, they compare it to the CAT scan. The CAT scan says there maybe new but more intense. Uh, but bone scans trump CAT scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm, so, we could technically say that that’s stable. Um. They comment more about your jaw this time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: They’re saying that it’s more intense. Uh, and they’re saying this could be more cancer then, you know, dental disease. Patient: Okay.

Patient: No. Um, none at this time. Doctor: Okay. So, what we’ll do is we’ll um we’ll be able to answer some questions over the phone when we call you as well in about a week. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Talk to you about the clinical trials. If you read through this and you say thanks but no thanks, that’s perfectly fine. I’m still going to be your doc and I’m still going to be your oncologist. Um and you have every right you know to turn this down if it’s not right for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But this a reasonable option that um if I was the patient, I would also consider. So I will leave that with you, put that underneath this one. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then uh we will get back in touch with you either later this week- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Or early next week. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And uh-

Family Member: Potassium. Doctor: Oh. Patient: Potassium and antibiotics. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Oh, your potassium is off. They came back two days later and said, oh, it was a little off. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Potassium was a little off. Doctor: Okay. We’ll, we’ll check you out for that. You know? You’re here because when Dr. S___, he did the lung biopsy or at least he told those guys to do a lung biopsy, it shows prostate cancer in your lungs. So not lung cancer. So in some sense a little bit of a relief but you still have your cancer of the – Patient: Of the prostate. Doctor: - prostate in your lungs. Now, you had that in twenty sixteen. It’s just that there’s more of it and slightly bigger. So that’s why I got you. When I went to, I sent you to Dr. S___, it was like well what are we going to do? Well, I need to take a sample. So he thought about going down this way. If you remember to try to get a sample from that, but he thought getting it through the outside would be just fine. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Which way did it get it? From the left side or right side?

Patient: That’s it. Doctor: No other medicines for pain, anything else for the allergies – Patient: No. Doctor: Or vitamins? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And when you were in the hospital, did they put any tubes or anything in, anything of that you still have. Patient: Yes, they put catheter in and uh they gave me I.V. at the beginning and made sure the catheter was out. Doctor: The catheter is out now? Patient: Now it’s not; See that is the problem. Uh catheter was not out when it was supposed to be scheduled; the catheter but two days before it was supposed to be taken out I Doctor: Even with the catheter in? Patient: Well, the catheter was blocked. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So I went again back to the emergency hospital and they made a mistake; they pulled it out. I still couldn’t pee. And I had peeing, but very little at the time. So they said it’s not doing it properly, so they put catheter back in. And they told me they shouldn’t have taken out. So the urologist told me; they should have flushed it and anyway, so.
